Ethylene Oxide and Propylene Oxide are reacted individually or in series with other raw materials to form the majority of our products.  Therefore , the use of EO and PO is considered as one process for our site.

All of the prevention program elements are common to both systems, except for two additional safeguards or mitigation measures on the EO storage.  Both EO and PO storage employ diking,  pressure, temperature and level control and alarms, and suitable safety relief devices.  In addition, EO storage utilizes a cooling exchanger to keep the stored EO below 45 degrees F and has a provision to send the EO through an emergency scrubber equipped with a sulfuric acid quench.

The site Prevention Program is managed by the Plant Engineer and the Environmental Engineer and includes:

1.)  Employee Participation
Employees are encouraged to participate in site prevention programs to promote awareness and to allow input from all site personnel into managing the safety of our facility and personnel.  Specific means of employee participatin in process safety and accident prevention are outlined in the Employee Participatin procedure in the site PSM manual.

2.)  Process Safety Information
Process Safety Information including piping and instrument diagrams, flow diagrams, material safety data sheets, technical data sheets, relief device calculatins, equipment files for design specifications, etc. is maintained and readily accessible to all employees.  The PSI used for the initial PHA's and subsequent revalidations is listed with that particular PHA and includes pointers to the location of each piece of information.

3.)  Process Hazard Analysis
Initial Process Hazard Analyses for all parts of our process were performed and are documented with appropriate reports.  Revalidations of these PHA's are being performed according to the OSHA PSM five-year schedule.  The findings of the PHA's, appropriate risk mitigation improvements, and responsible personnel are compiled into a spreadsheet which is used by the Project Engineer to track the mitigation to completion.

4.)  Operating Procedures
Document-controlled standard operating procedures and manufacturing procedures are readily available to the process operator to ensure safe and consistent operation of the process.  These procedures are annually reviewed and certified as being currently accurate and correct.

5.)  Training
A training program administers and tracks all requisite training which includes OSHA-mandated operator process training and refresher, emergency response to spills, releases, fires, and explosions, and hazard awareness and control.  Training documentation and verification of understanding are kept in the central files.  Personnel records are also maintained and tracked electronically via the "TrainingMine" program.

6.)  Contractors
Contractors are selected based on their safety record and performance as documented on the required pre-qualification form.  Site orientation training on the hazards present and the safety and emergency proccedures is administered to each contract employee before work on-site is allowed.  A post-project evaluation of the firm's safety performance is completed by site personnel to document adherence to site policies and procedures and safe work practices.

7.)  Pre-startup Safety Review
Pre-startup Safety Reviews of all equipment alterations are conducted to ensure hazards uncovered during the PHA phase of the project are corrected and that the equipment is ready for safe use.

8.)  Mechanical Integrity
A comprehensive mechanical integrity and preventive maintenance program is in place to monitor equipment integrity and performance and to ensure operation of all safety systems.

9.)  Safe Work
Safe Work, Hot Work, Lock Out/Tag Out and Confined Space Entry permit programs are used to safeguard personnel and prevent accidents and incidents during maintenance activities.

10.)  Management of Change
A procedure to manage all changes to equipment and facilities is used to ensure the hazards of the modification are mitigated and all personnel are informed of the alterations.  The procedure and the appropriate forms can be found in the site procedures manual.

11.)  Incident Investigation
The site utilizes an incident, near miss and suggestion reporting database with whole site access to report safety, environmental, process and quality incidents and near miss incidents and to suggest improvements in any of these categories.  This database and accompanying procedure, provide for review and investigation by staff members, suggestion of corrective actions, tracking of completion of these actions and communication to appropriate personnel of incidents and steps taken to prevent recurrence.

12.)  Compliance Audits
Site personnel conduct audits of the facilities and systems to ensure potential hazards are detected and corrected and that site systems are functioning appropriately to prevent mishap.  In addition to the requisite compliance audits of the process safety and accident prevention systems, perfunctory audits are conducted on parts of these programs such as safe work permitting systems and inspection records.  However, only the compliance audits are officially documented and kept on file for review.
The formaldehyde reaction process involves an aqueous solution of formaldehyde and amines.  All of the prevention program elements described in Process ID 1 are applicable to Process ID 2.

The carbon disulfide reaction process involves a mixture of carbon disulfide, 50% caustic soda solution and an aqueous polyamine solution.  All of the prevention program elements described in Process ID 1 are applicable to Process ID 3.

A.  Executive Summary
This RMP has been updated to reflect the addition of one new chemical (CS2) which is scheduled for delivery to the plant site the later part of May 2009.  The last RMP was submitted June 21, 2004.

At the Nalco Freeport Plant, we are committed to operating and to maintaining our process in a manner that is safe for our employees, the public and the environment.  As part of this commitment, we have established a Risk Management Program (RMP) that complies with the requirements of the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA's) regulation 40 CFR Part 68, Accidental Release Prevention Requirements: Risk Managemet Program (the RMP rule).  One element of the RMP rule is a Risk Managemet Plan (RMPlan) which details accident prevention measures and safeguards.  This document is intended to satisfy the RMPlan requirements of the RMP rule and to provide the public with a description of our risk managemt program.

1.  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Accidental release prevention and emergency response planning programs are vital to ensure the safety of our employees, the community and the environment.  The Nalco Freeport Plant implements reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of the hazardous substances we use.  In the event of a significant accidental release, trained responders will act to control and contain the release.  We work with local emergency response organizations to evaluate potential releases and to formulate appropriate responses to contain and to prevent and/or reduce the consequences of such a release.  Nalco in conjunction with the local emergency planning and response organizations, has established a means to warn the surrounding communities in the event of a release which would threaten the public.

2.  Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

Nalco operates a manufacturing facility at the Freeport site in Brazoria County, Texas.  This batch-process facility produces a wide variety of mater

ials for use in oil field and water treatment applications.  Ethylene Oxide and Propylene Oxide are reacted individually or in series with other raw materials to form the majority of our products.  In our oxyalkylation process, Ethylene Oxide and Propylene Oxide are the only RMP regulated chemicals that are present above the EPA threshold quantity.  In our Formaldehyde Reaction process, Formaldehyde (50% aqueous) and Methylamine (50% aqueous) are the only RMP regulated chemicals present above the EPA threshold quantity.  In our Carbon Disulfide Reaction process, Carbon Disulfide is the only RMP regulated chemical present above the EPA threshold quantity.  For the purpose of this RMPlan, the use of EO and PO is considered as one process for our site.

Program Level:  3;  Regulated Substance:  Ethylene Oxide;  Type:  Toxic
Program Level:  3;  Regulated Substance:  Propylene Oxide;  Type:  Toxic
Program Level:  3;  Regulated Substance:  Formaldehyde;  Type:  Toxic
Program Level:  3;  Regulated Substance:  Methylamine;  Type:  Flammable
Program Level:  3;  Regulated Substance:  Carbon Disulfide;  Type:  Toxic

3.  Key Offsite Consequence Analysis Scenarios

This section has been left blank based on the EPA Amendment to the RMP rule on April 9, 2004 (69CFR18819).

4.  General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Accident prevention is our top priority and a vital part of our business.  A number of programs are in place at our facility to prevent accidental releases and to ensure safe operation.  These programs include:

-  Process Safety Information
-  Process Hazard Analysis
-  Incident Reporting and Investigation
-  Mechanical Integrity Program
-  Training Program
-  Emergency Response
-  Standard Operating Procedures
-  Critical Safe Work Permitting System
-  Management of Change System
-  Pre-Startup Safety Reviews
-  Contractor Safety Program
-  Compliance Audit Program
-  Employee Participation Program
-  Safety Instrumented

System (SIS) Program

In addition to the accident prevention programs, we have implemented the following chemical-specific prevention measures:

-  Release Detection
-  Hydrocarbon Detection with Alarms
-  Process alarms
-  Remote cameras
-  Release Containment and Control
-  Relief valves on process equipment discharging to flare
-  Emergency vent scrubber on EO storage
-  Automated and manual valves to allow for process isolation
-  Interlocks on specific process parameters to provide automatic shutdown
-  Curbing and diking to contain liquid releases
-  Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g. uninterruptible power supply on process control system, back-up firewater pumps)
-  Atmospheric relief devices

Release Mitigation
-  Fire suppression and extinguishing systems
-  Deluge system for specific equipment
-  Trained emergency response personnel
-  Blast resistant control room to help protect personnel and control systems

5.  Five-Year Accident History

In the past five years, this facility has experienced one (1) accidental release.  This accidental release resulted in one (1) employee being directly exposed to a chemical.  There were no deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on-site or off-site, or any evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.  Work in the plant was stopped and employees were notified to proceed upwind of the release.

6.  Emergency Response Program

Our facility maintains an emergency response and contingency plan, which meets all of the federal, state and local regulatory requirements and is communicated to all employees.  This plan and the emergency response training for the site personnel provide protection for our employees, the public and the environment.

Representatives of our facility are active members of Brazosport's Community Awareness and Emergency Response (CAER) group, the Brazoria County Petrochemical Council (BCPC), the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and the Brazospo

rt Emergency Planning Committee (BEPC).  All of these groups work to improve the communication between the chemical companies about emergency response and mitigation.  Furthermore, we share information to better enable us to protect our workers, communities and environment and to prevent accidental releases.

Regular drills involving on-site emergency responders, the local fire department and the local industrial mutual aid team are conducted.  These drills are based on scenarios of fires, explosions and/or toxic releases and may involve any or all of the above response organizations.

7.  Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The following improvements were identified during Process Hazard Analysis at our facility:

Improvements already completed include:

1.)  Review of relief systems for adequacy and change as necessary to handle worst emergency case.
2.)  Addition of more alarms and reviews of set points of existing alarms for adequacy.
3.)  Addition of more instrumentation to better monitor process conditions at more points along the process train.
4.)  Installation of back-flow prevention measures to avert hazardous contamination or mixing of incompatible chemicals.
5.)  Revision of standard operation procedures to clarify process steps and to eliminate possible confusion or error.
6.)  Established a mechanical integrity and preventin maintenance program to monitor critical equipment and instrumentation and to minimize unforseen failures.
7.)  Installation of vent flare to incinerate all vent gases and minimize hazardous material release during an emergency venting situation.
8.)  Updated all plant drawings to reflect equipment and piping changes to provide an accurate tool for site personnel.
9.)  Revalidation of the initial Process Hazard Analyses have been compleeted to meet the five year revalidation frequency per OSHA.
10.)  Implementation of Safety Instrumented Systems program.
11.)  Increase employee awareness through additional training.

Planned improvem

ents include:

1.)  Further automation of process equipment to minimize the opportunity for human error.
2.)  Addition of more instrumentation to allow for closer monitoring of process conditions and installatin of more interlocks to provide additional safeguards against accidents.
3.)  Continue the Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation process based on the five year review frequency to verify that all hazards uncovered initially have been satisfactorily mitigated and to determine that no new hazards have been introduced.
